title: Blue jelly

| A blue jelly:* can flow under doors.
* [does not breathe](/wiki/Breathless "Breathless").
* cannot pick up items.
* has [no eyes](/wiki/Eyeless "Eyeless").
* has no limbs.
* has no head.
* is [mindless](/wiki/Mindless "Mindless").
* [does not eat](/wiki/Inediate "Inediate"). (\*)
* is neither male nor female.
* is normally generated [hostile](/wiki/Hostile "Hostile"). |                                                    |
|                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |                                                    |
| **[Reference](/wiki/Source_code "Source code")**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   | [monst.c#line503](/wiki/Monst.c#line503 "Monst.c") |

A **blue jelly**, j, is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. Like most [jellies](/wiki/Jellies "Jellies"), it is [eyeless](/wiki/Eyeless "Eyeless"), [amorphous](/wiki/Amorphous "Amorphous"), and [sessile](/wiki/Sessile "Sessile").

A blue jelly has a [passive attack](/wiki/Passive_attack "Passive attack") that triggers if attacked in melee, dealing [cold](/wiki/Cold "Cold") damage against attackers without [cold resistance](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance") dependent on their level while increasing the jelly's HP by half the damage inflicted[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)[\[4\]](#cite_note-4) - if enough HP is gained from this, the jelly will undergo [division](/wiki/Division "Division"), halving its HP (rounded up) and creating a second jelly with almost the same amount of HP.[\[5\]](#cite_note-5)[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7) Blue jellies possess [poison resistance](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance") and cold resistance.

[Eating](/wiki/Eating "Eating") a blue jelly [corpse](/wiki/Corpse "Corpse") or [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin") has roughly a 2⁄15 chance each (13%) of conferring cold resistance or poison resistance.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Variants](#Variants)

  - [4.1 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [4.2 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)
  - [4.3 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [5 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [6 References](#References)

## Generation

Randomly generated blue jellies are always created hostile.

Blue jellies appear among the j that make up the second [quest](/wiki/Quest "Quest") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class") for [Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight"), and makes up 6⁄175 of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [Knight quest](/wiki/Knight_quest "Knight quest").

## Strategy

Avoid attacking a blue jelly in melee unless you have cold resistance: blue jellies are much tougher than might be expected, and their cold passive attack can be deadly to inexperienced [players](/wiki/Player "Player"). At their base level, they do (4+1)d6 damage, which gives a range of 5–30, and they can be generated at much higher levels. [Ranged attacks](/wiki/Ranged_attack "Ranged attack") are preferable, but make sure you have enough charges or projectiles options to finish the job—projectiles in particular will not be retrievable until the jelly is dead.

A [lance](/wiki/Lance "Lance") or [polearm](/wiki/Polearm "Polearm") can pound away safely at a distance and take a blue jelly out easily, and sources of [fire](/wiki/Fire "Fire") damage can also make short work of them. The [aklys](/wiki/Aklys "Aklys") is a solid option for throwable weapons that should likely be prioritized below pounding, but above other thrown weapons: at worst, the aklys has a 1⁄100 chance of failing to return, but will most likely deal enough damage for a [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") to finish it with any remaining projectiles, preserving valuable [darts](/wiki/Darts "Darts"), [wand](/wiki/Wand "Wand") charges and/or other items.

Blue jellies are frequently employed for [boulder forts](/wiki/Boulder_fort "Boulder fort"), [stashes](/wiki/Stash "Stash") and the like, since they are completely immobile and their damage is easier to resist.

## History

The blue jelly first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

In [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3") and earlier versions, including some variants based on those versions, blue jellies can be instrumental in [farming](/wiki/Death_farming "Death farming") the [Rider](/wiki/Rider "Rider") Death.

## Variants

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), a blue jelly appears in the northeastern-most room of [Asmodeus' Lair](/wiki/Asmodeus%27_Lair_\(UnNetHack\) "Asmodeus' Lair (UnNetHack)").

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), a blue jelly appears in the northeastern-most room of [Asmodeus' Lair](/wiki/Asmodeus%27_Lair_\(SpliceHack\) "Asmodeus' Lair (SpliceHack)") as in UnNetHack.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), blue jellies are [vulnerable](/wiki/Vulnerable "Vulnerable") to [fire](/wiki/Fire "Fire"). This also applies to [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM").

## Encyclopedia entry

I'd planned how to prevent the lock from sealing behind me; it required a temporary sacrifice, not cleverness. I used the door itself to help me cut off a portion of my body, after shunting all memory from the piece to be abandoned. The piece, looking inexpressibly dear and forlorn for a bit of blue jelly, would force open the outer door until I returned and rejoined it.

\[ Beholder's Eye, by Julie E. Czerneda ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2917](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/uhitm.c#L2917): *case for cold passive against you*
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2927](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/uhitm.c#L2927): *cold passive healing against you*
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1671](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitm.c#L1671): *case for cold passive against monsters*
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1682](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitm.c#L1682): *cold passive healing against monsters*
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2933](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/uhitm.c#L2933): *case against you calls `split_mon` function in [potion.c](/wiki/Potion.c "Potion.c")*
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1685](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mhitm.c#L1685): *case against monsters also calls `split_mon` function in [potion.c](/wiki/Potion.c "Potion.c")*
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [src/potion.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2379](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/potion.c#L2379)

Frequency (by normal means) 2 (Quite rare)
Genocidable Yes

Resistances conveyed Cold (13%), poison (13%)

A blue jelly:

  • can flow under doors.
  • does not breathe.
  • cannot pick up items.
  • has no eyes.
  • has no limbs.
  • has no head.
  • is mindless.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is neither male nor female.
  • is normally generated hostile.
Reference monst.c#line503

A blue jelly, j, is a type of monster that appears in NetHack. Like most jellies, it is eyeless, amorphous, and sessile.

A blue jelly has a passive attack that triggers if attacked in melee, dealing cold damage against attackers without cold resistance dependent on their level while increasing the jelly's HP by half the damage inflicted[1][2][3][4] - if enough HP is gained from this, the jelly will undergo division, halving its HP (rounded up) and creating a second jelly with almost the same amount of HP.[5][6][7] Blue jellies possess poison resistance and cold resistance.

Eating a blue jelly corpse or tin has roughly a 2⁄15 chance each (13%) of conferring cold resistance or poison resistance.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Variants
    • 4.1 UnNetHack
    • 4.2 SpliceHack
    • 4.3 EvilHack
  • 5 Encyclopedia entry
  • 6 References

Generation

Randomly generated blue jellies are always created hostile.

Blue jellies appear among the j that make up the second quest monster class for Knights, and makes up 6⁄175 of the monsters that are randomly generated on the Knight quest.

Strategy

Avoid attacking a blue jelly in melee unless you have cold resistance: blue jellies are much tougher than might be expected, and their cold passive attack can be deadly to inexperienced players. At their base level, they do (4+1)d6 damage, which gives a range of 5–30, and they can be generated at much higher levels. Ranged attacks are preferable, but make sure you have enough charges or projectiles options to finish the job—projectiles in particular will not be retrievable until the jelly is dead.

A lance or polearm can pound away safely at a distance and take a blue jelly out easily, and sources of fire damage can also make short work of them. The aklys is a solid option for throwable weapons that should likely be prioritized below pounding, but above other thrown weapons: at worst, the aklys has a 1⁄100 chance of failing to return, but will most likely deal enough damage for a hero to finish it with any remaining projectiles, preserving valuable darts, wand charges and/or other items.

Blue jellies are frequently employed for boulder forts, stashes and the like, since they are completely immobile and their damage is easier to resist.

History

The blue jelly first appears in NetHack 3.0.0.

In NetHack 3.4.3 and earlier versions, including some variants based on those versions, blue jellies can be instrumental in farming the Rider Death.

Variants

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, a blue jelly appears in the northeastern-most room of Asmodeus' Lair.

SpliceHack

In SpliceHack, a blue jelly appears in the northeastern-most room of Asmodeus' Lair as in UnNetHack.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, blue jellies are vulnerable to fire. This also applies to Hack'EM.

Encyclopedia entry

I'd planned how to prevent the lock from sealing behind me; it required a temporary sacrifice, not cleverness. I used the door itself to help me cut off a portion of my body, after shunting all memory from the piece to be abandoned. The piece, looking inexpressibly dear and forlorn for a bit of blue jelly, would force open the outer door until I returned and rejoined it.

[ Beholder's Eye, by Julie E. Czerneda ]

References

  1. ↑ src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2917: case for cold passive against you
  2. ↑ src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2927: cold passive healing against you
  3. ↑ src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1671: case for cold passive against monsters
  4. ↑ src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1682: cold passive healing against monsters
  5. ↑ src/uhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2933: case against you calls split_mon function in potion.c
  6. ↑ src/mhitm.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1685: case against monsters also calls split_mon function in potion.c
  7. ↑ src/potion.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2379

Like most [[jellies]], it is [[eyeless]], [[amorphous]], and [[sessile]]. A blue jelly has a [[passive attack]] that triggers if attacked in melee, dealing [[cold]] damage against attackers without [[cold resistance]] dependent on their level while increasing the jelly's HP by half the damage inflicted{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|2917|nethack=3.6.7|comment=case for cold passive against you}}{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|2927|nethack=3.6.7|comment=cold passive healing against you}}{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1671|nethack=3.6.7|comment=case for cold passive against monsters}}{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1682|nethack=3.6.7|comment=cold passive healing against monsters}} - if enough HP is gained from this, the jelly will undergo [[division]], halving its HP (rounded up) and creating a second jelly with almost the same amount of HP.{{refsrc|src/uhitm.c|2933|nethack=3.6.7|comment=case against you calls split_mon function in [[potion.c]]}}{{refsrc|src/mhitm.c|1685|nethack=3.6.7|comment=case against monsters also calls split_mon function in [[potion.c]]}}{{refsrc|src/potion.c|2379|nethack=3.6.7|split_mon function - the "extra" hit point from halving an odd value is given to the original jelly}} Blue jellies possess [[poison resistance]] and cold resistance. [[Eating]] a blue jelly [[corpse]] or [[tin]] has roughly a {{frac|2|15}} chance each (13%) of conferring cold resistance or poison resistance. ==Generation== Randomly generated blue jellies are always created hostile. Blue jellies appear among the {{white|j}} that make up the second [[quest]] [[monster class]] for [[Knight]]s, and makes up {{frac|6|175}} of the monsters that are randomly generated on the [[Knight quest]]. ==Strategy== Avoid attacking a blue jelly in melee unless you have cold resistance: blue jellies are much tougher than might be expected, and their cold passive attack can be deadly to inexperienced [[player]]s. At their base level, they do (4+1)d6 damage, which gives a range of 5–30, and they can be generated at much higher levels. [[Ranged attack]]s are preferable, but make sure you have enough charges or projectiles options to finish the job—projectiles in particular will not be retrievable until the jelly is dead. A [[lance]] or [[polearm]] can pound away safely at a distance and take a blue jelly out easily, and sources of [[fire]] damage can also make short work of them. The [[aklys]] is a solid option for throwable weapons that should likely be prioritized below pounding, but above other thrown weapons: at worst, the aklys has a {{frac|100}} chance of failing to return, but will most likely deal enough damage for a [[hero]] to finish it with any remaining projectiles, preserving valuable [[darts]], [[wand]] charges and/or other items. Blue jellies are frequently employed for [[boulder fort]]s, [[stash]]es and the like, since they are completely immobile and their damage is easier to resist. ==History== The blue jelly first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]]. In [[NetHack 3.4.3]] and earlier versions, including some variants based on those versions, blue jellies can be instrumental in [[Death farming|farming]] the [[Rider]] Death. ==Variants== ===UnNetHack=== In [[UnNetHack]], a blue jelly appears in the northeastern-most room of [[Asmodeus' Lair (UnNetHack)|Asmodeus' Lair]]. ===SpliceHack=== In [[SpliceHack]], a blue jelly appears in the northeastern-most room of [[Asmodeus' Lair (SpliceHack)|Asmodeus' Lair]] as in UnNetHack. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], blue jellies are [[vulnerable]] to [[fire]]. This also applies to [[Hack'EM]]. ==Encyclopedia entry== {{encyclopedia| I'd planned how to prevent the lock from sealing behind me; it required a temporary sacrifice, not cleverness. I used the door itself to help me cut off a portion of my body, after shunting all memory from the piece to be abandoned. The piece, looking inexpressibly dear and forlorn for a bit of blue jelly, would force open the outer door until I returned and rejoined it. |[ Beholder's Eye, by Julie E.
